author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Standing by his decision to impeach, Peter Meijer says he ‘may very well have’ ended his career.
description: Representative Peter Meijer acknowledged on Sunday that “I may very well have” ended my career after joining nine other Republicans who voted last week to impeach President Trump.
content: Representative Peter Meijer acknowledged on Sunday that “I may very well have” ended my career after joining nine other Republicans who voted last week to impeach President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: A CBS outage temporarily left some East Coast football fans in the dark.
description: A CBS broadcast of the N.F.L. playoff game between the Cleveland Browns and Kansas City Chiefs was briefly cut off for viewers in New York and some other areas on the East Coast on Sunday, prompting complaints and confusion among viewers and a scramble to find other ways to watch the game.
content: A CBS broadcast of the N.F.L. playoff game between the Cleveland Browns and Kansas City Chiefs was briefly cut off for viewers in New York and some other areas on the East Coast on Sunday, prompting complaints and confusion among viewers and a scramble to find other ways to watch the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The Pentagon warns adversaries that domestic terrorist threats won’t distract it from foreign ones.
description: As thousands of National Guard troops continued to flow into Washington ahead of Inauguration Day, the Pentagon on Sunday sent another strong signal to Iran and other potential adversaries in the Middle East not to exploit the nation’s focus on domestic terrorist threats to carry out attacks against Americans in the region.
content: As thousands of National Guard troops continued to flow into Washington ahead of Inauguration Day, the Pentagon on Sunday sent another strong signal to Iran and other potential adversaries in the Middle East not to exploit the nation’s focus on domestic terrorist threats to carry out attacks against Americans in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The police arrested a woman who they said impersonated an officer at an inauguration checkpoint.
description: The authorities said the woman falsely claimed she was a police officer and a member of the president’s cabinet.
content: U.S. Capitol Police have arrested a woman they said drove up to an inauguration checkpoint and falsely claimed she was a police officer and a member of the president’s cabinet, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple and Nic Wirtz
title: Migrant Caravan, Now in Guatemala, Tests Regional Resolve to Control Migration
description: As many as 7,000 migrants from Central America are hoping to reach the United States to escape poverty intensified by hurricanes and the pandemic. President-elect Joseph R.  Biden Jr. has pledged to ease asylum rules.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Valve Turners’
description: How a group of five activists decided to fight global warming by doing whatever it takes.
content: Most Americans treat climate change seriously but not literally — they accept the science, worry about forecasts but tell themselves that someone else will get serious about fixing the problem very soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: What’s It Like to Have Kamala Harris as ‘Momala’? We Asked Her Stepkids
description: A Zoom interview with Ella and Cole Emhoff.
content: Before November, most people didn’t know the names Cole and Ella Emhoff. Cole, 26, was working at a production company in Los Angeles, living with his girlfriend. Ella, 21, was an art student in New York, living in Bushwick, and posting pictures of her knitting designs on Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Running for the Doors
description: In his final days in office, President Trump is losing more longtime allies in the business world.
content: Happy Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Here’s the business and tech news you need to know for the week ahead. Stay safe, everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: How Twitter Coaxed Its Boss on Trump Ban
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 17, 2021.
content: “This is a phenomenal exercise of power to de-platform the president of the United States. It should set off a broader reckoning.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh, Mike Baker, Patricia Mazzei and Mark Walker
title: One Year, 400,000 Coronavirus Deaths: How the U.S. Guaranteed Its Own Failure
description: After the White House declined to pursue a unified national strategy, governors faced off against lobbyists, health experts and a restless public consumed by misinformation.
content: The path to beating the coronavirus was clear, but Kelley Vollmar had never felt so helpless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Occhicone and David Gonzalez
title: Inside a Nursing Home as Vaccine Arrives: ‘I Hope Everybody Takes It’
description: At a Staten Island facility that was hit hard by the coronavirus, residents and staff members lined up to get a dose of the Covid vaccine. Here’s how the day went.
content: [Here’s how you can get the coronavirus vaccine in NYC.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From the N.F.L.’s Divisional Round
description: Buffalo rode its defense, Green Bay thrived on offense and Tampa Bay let Drew Brees beat himself. Kansas City, which lost Patrick Mahomes to a concussion, simply survived.
content: Home teams won three of four games during the N.F.L.’s divisional round, but there was plenty of fretting along the way. The Buffalo Bills rode their defense to a win, the Green Bay Packers relied on their offense and the heavily favored Kansas City Chiefs, who lost quarterback Patrick Mahomes to a concussion, mostly just survived. The weekend closed with a hyped battle in New Orleans between N.F.L. legends — Tom Brady of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Drew Brees of the Saints — that resulted in the round’s lone upset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Erin Griffith
title: Peloton’s Rapid Rise Is Threatened by Its Slow Delivery
description: The company has boomed in popularity during the pandemic but getting its exercise bikes delivered has proved a struggle, one that is angering new customers.
content: Peloton’s relentlessly positive Instagram posts usually attract enthusiastic responses from its 1.2 million followers, who love the company’s charismatic instructors and its $1,900-plus bikes and treadmills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Patrick Mahomes is out with a concussion after third-quarter hit.
description: Backup Chad Henne took over with the Browns closing in on the Chiefs’ lead.
content: [Follow our live Browns vs Chiefs coverage.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Kamala Harris Will Make History. So Will Her ‘Big, Blended’ Family.
description: Stepkids. Nieces. A doting husband. His ex-wife. What the Harris-Emhoffs can show the country.
content: When Kamala Harris is sworn in as vice president, she will represent many firsts: First woman vice president. First Black woman. First woman of Indian descent. But there is another milestone that will be on display: that of her family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Social Media Posts Lead to Arrest of N.Y. Man for Role in Capitol Riot
description: In several videos on Facebook, the man, Edward Jacob Lang, could be seen in the mob outside the building in Washington.
content: A 25-year-old New York man from the Hudson Valley was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents at his home on Saturday after he posted photos and videos on social media placing him outside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 during the rampage by violent extremists.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 17, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 17, 2021.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Page 5 about rape-revenge films misspells the given name of the actress who plays the protagonist in “Promising Young Woman.” She is Carey Mulligan, not Carrie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Movies to Stream for Martin Luther King Jr. Day
description: Seven recent films help commemorate King’s legacy in fighting for racial justice.
content: With each year since it was designated as a holiday in 1983, Martin Luther King Jr. Day has carried new yet immovable significance. It did so the year following Rodney King’s 1991 assault. It did so in the years following the deaths of Oscar Grant, Trayvon Martin, Michael Brown and Freddie Gray. And now, following the past year’s deaths of Representative John Lewis and the Rev. C.T. Vivian, the killings of Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, the arrival of the summer’s Black Lives Matter protests, the November presidential election and this month’s storming of the Capitol by a pro-Trump mob, the holiday carries that much more meaning. In our government, in our elections, and in our law enforcement the signs of racism still lurk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Children Shrieked in Delight as the Honking Train Passed Below’
description: Waiting on a bridge, getting carried away while dining out and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: States are scrambling after the Trump administration’s vaccine promise falls apart.
description: The stockpile of doses was nearly empty.
content: After a promise from the Trump administration that it would release a stockpile of reserved coronavirus vaccine doses, several states were expecting a huge boost in doses. Some followed federal guidance to expand eligibility to wider swaths of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: More Than 760,000 Pounds of Hot Pockets Recalled
description: Nestlé Prepared Foods said the product might be contaminated with “extraneous materials,” including glass and hard plastic.
content: Nestlé Prepared Foods has recalled more than 700,000 pounds of frozen pepperoni Hot Pockets that may contain pieces of glass and hard plastic, the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: A QAnon ‘Digital Soldier’ Marches On, Undeterred by Theory’s Unraveling
description: Valerie Gilbert posts dozens of times a day in support of an unhinged conspiracy theory. The story of this “meme queen” hints at how hard it will be to bring people like her back to reality.
content: Every morning, Valerie Gilbert, a Harvard-educated writer and actress, wakes up in her Upper East Side apartment; feeds her dog, Milo, and her cats, Marlena and Celeste; brews a cup of coffee; and sits down at her oval dining room table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Navalny Arrested on Return to Moscow in Battle of Wills With Putin
description: Aleksei Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, landed in Russia Sunday night five months after he was poisoned with a nerve agent.
content: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny returned to his home country Sunday, five months after a near-fatal nerve-agent attack, and was arrested at the border, a show of fearlessness by Russia’s most prominent opposition leader and of anxiety by President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA’s Mega Rocket to the Moon Faces Setback After Test
description: A test firing of the engines of the Space Launch System was halted after only about a minute, meaning NASA astronauts may have to wait longer before setting foot on the moon again.
content: After billions of dollars and a decade of work, NASA’s plans to send astronauts back to the moon had a new setback on Saturday. A planned eight-minute test firing of the four engines of a new mega rocket needed for the moon missions came to an abrupt end after only about a minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: How to Celebrate Martin Luther King’s Birthday in 2021
description: Here are ways to commemorate Dr. King’s legacy, whether you want to commit to a day of service or learn about the history of the civil rights movement.
content: Martin Luther King’s Birthday, a federal holiday observed on the third Monday in January, is a time to reflect on the legacy of the influential civil rights leader. It is also a federal holiday dedicated to a day of service, when Americans are encouraged to heed Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s words: “Everybody can be great, because everybody can serve.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: Six Great Movies About Presidents
description: If you’re looking for some escapism, these films are a good reminder that democracy works.
content: When a new president is inaugurated, it’s traditionally an occasion for pageantry and pomp, showcasing the splendor of Washington and reminding the country and the world of the United States’ democratic promise: that power ultimately rests in the will of the people. As we head into these ceremonies next week, it’s a good time to let these movies remind us that the mechanisms of American politics and the institution of the presidency — at their best and worst — have endured for centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Cargo Ship Sinks Near Turkey, Leaving at Least 3 Dead, Officials Say
description: Emergency workers saved half the 12-member crew after the vessel sank off the Black Sea coast, state media said, but bad weather hindered further rescue efforts.
content: A cargo ship sank off Turkey’s Black Sea coast near the northern province of Bartin on Sunday, leaving at least three people dead, according to Turkish state media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: The Browns’ fumble for a touchback prompted reaction to controversial rule.
description: The rules state that if a team fumbles the ball and it goes out of the opponent’s end zone, the play results in a touchback.
content: What a devastating sequence of events for the Browns, who lost a touchdown — and gave possession back to Kansas City — after receiver Rashard Higgins fumbled the ball out of the back of the end zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
title: Thai Caves Attract Millions of Bats — and Now Scientists Too
description: A cave complex at a temple in Thailand has long drawn tourists, pilgrims and guano collectors. Now, scientists have arrived, looking for any potential links to the coronavirus.
content: PHOTHARAM, Thailand — The bat caves reeked of bat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: A Trip Into the Otherworldly With Adrienne Kennedy as Guide
description: A digital four-play retrospective, capped by a world premiere, illuminates this writer’s fascination with doubling, violence and Black identity.
content: Have you experienced the familiar unfamiliarity of dreams? That quixotic sense of déjà vu that comes from snippets of memory, stray thoughts, recurring images stolen from the day or drawn wholly from the imagination — all jigsaw-puzzled together to form a portrait of a feeling, a sensation, a belief or fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Pawel
title: Kevin McCarthy Finds That Charm Has Its Limits
description: Many people will not forgive the Republican House leader’s blatant acts to embrace and perpetuate dangerous lies that threatened democracy.
content: LOS ANGELES — Here is the important thing to understand about Kevin McCarthy: He has risen from college dropout to the highest rungs of political leadership by being the guy everyone liked. You can’t have too many friends, he likes to say. He was the guy with the pool table in the house he shared with legislators in Sacramento; the guy who slept on the sofa in his congressional office, went mountain biking with colleagues in the morning and hosted movie nights with Chick-fil-A; the guy who could deliver votes and raise money. Everyone, it seemed, liked the California Republican whom President Trump called “my Kevin.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: How a Historian Got Close, Maybe Too Close, to a Nazi Thief
description: Over nearly a decade, Jonathan Petropoulos met dozens of times with a man who helped the Nazis loot Jewish art collections, a complicated relationship he explores in “Göring’s Man in Paris.”
content: By the late 1990s, most of the Nazi art experts who helped loot European Jews were either dead or living quiet lives under the radar. Not so Bruno Lohse, who served as the art agent to the Reichsmarschall Hermann Göring, Hitler’s right-hand man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: How Republicans Are Warping Reality Around the Capitol Attack
description: Loyalists to President Trump are increasingly relying on conspiracy theories and misinformation, drawing false equivalence with last summer’s racial protests and blaming outside agitators.
content: Immediately after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, all corners of the political spectrum repudiated the mob of President Trump’s supporters. Yet within days, prominent Republicans, party officials, conservative media voices and rank-and-file voters began making a rhetorical shift to try to downplay the group’s violent actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Tiffany Hsu
title: Behind a Secret Deal Between Google and Facebook
description: Facebook was going to compete with Google for some advertising sales but backed away from the plan after the companies cut a preferential deal, according to court documents.
content: In 2017, Facebook said it was testing a new way of selling online advertising that would threaten Google’s control of the digital ad market. But less than two years later, Facebook did an about-face and said it was joining an alliance of companies backing a similar effort by Google.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Inauguration, Vaccines, Regina King: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: How the Kansas City Chiefs beat the Cleveland Browns and reached the A.F.C. championship game.
description: With his star quarterback, Patrick Mahomes, gone from the game with a concussion, Coach Andy Reid went for it on fourth-and-1 from near midfield and converted, allowing Kansas City to run out the clock and preserve a 22-17 victory.
content: The Kansas City Chiefs’ best player, quarterback Patrick Mahomes, was out with a concussion. The team had just allowed touchdowns on consecutive drives. And Mahomes’s replacement, Chad Henne, had just been intercepted in the end zone, giving the Cleveland Browns a chance to thwart the Chiefs’ hopes of repeating as Super Bowl champions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Phil Spector, Famed Music Producer and Convicted Murderer, Dies at 81
description: Known for creating the ‘Wall of Sound,’ he scored hits with the Crystals, the Ronettes and the Righteous Brothers and was one of the most influential figures in popular music.
content: Phil Spector, one of the most influential and successful record producers in rock ’n’ roll, who generated a string of hits in the early 1960s  defined by the lavish instrumental treatment known as the wall of sound, but who was sentenced to prison for the murder of a woman at his home, died on Saturday. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Twitter temporarily suspends Marjorie Taylor Greene’s personal account.
description: Twitter temporarily suspends Marjorie Taylor Greene’s personal account.
content: Twitter has temporarily suspended the personal account of Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Georgia Republican and supporter of the QAnon conspiracy theory, citing “multiple violations” of the company’s civic integrity policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: How Biden’s Proposed Paid Leave Would Work
description: Paid leave expired in December for illness and caregiving during the pandemic. Biden wants to reinstate and expand it.
content: More Americans may soon be able to take more than three months of paid leave from work for sickness or to care for children and family members during the pandemic, if Congress approves a plan proposed by President-elect Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Nikolai Antoshkin, Who Helped Halt Chernobyl Disaster, Dies at 78
description: He survived radiation as commander of the operation that extinguished the Chernobyl nuclear plant fire. He died of the coronavirus.
content: MOSCOW — Gen. Nikolai T. Antoshkin, the commander of a perilous helicopter firefighting operation in which he and other pilots braved radiation exposure to contain the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, died on Sunday. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Eric Schmitt
title: State capitals are on edge and heavily patrolled after warnings of possible violence.
description: WASHINGTON — The atmosphere was tense in the nation’s capital and at statehouses across the country on Sunday, where military vehicles and police barricades lined the streets and officials braced for the possible influx of pro-Trump protests amid concerns about potential violence.
content: WASHINGTON — The atmosphere was tense in the nation’s capital and at statehouses across the country on Sunday, where military vehicles and police barricades lined the streets and officials braced for the possible influx of pro-Trump protests amid concerns about potential violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Emma Grillo
title: Attend a Jazz Festival and Take a Superhero Yoga Class
description: This week, celebrate Martin Luther King’s Birthday, revisit “The West Wing” and explore a new exhibit from the National Museum of Women in the Arts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Improve Your Life With These Tiny Chores
description: Completing these five home projects — like undergoing a good spring cleaning — will give you and your home a fresh start in the new year.
content: Being home all the time has been hard on your house, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Biden’s incoming chief of staff warns that the virus death toll will reach 500,000 by the end of February.
description: Ron Klain, who coordinated the Obama administration’s Ebola response, warns, “The virus is going to get worse before it gets better.”
content: Officials in the incoming Biden administration braced the country for continued hardship in the days after the inauguration, with the president-elect assuming control of a struggling economy and surging coronavirus outbreak in less than three days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Michael S. Schmidt
title: N.S.A. Installs Trump Loyalist as Top Lawyer Days Before Biden Takes Office
description: The acting defense secretary ordered the spy agency to appoint Michael Ellis, who has been accused of having a hand in one of the Trump administration’s most contentious legal decisions.
content: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency is moving forward with hiring a Trump administration loyalist, the agency said on Sunday, after the acting defense secretary ordered he be made the spy agency’s top lawyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Jamaican oxtail stew, white borscht, spicy noodles with chicken and peanuts: Transport yourself by way of your kitchen.
content: Good morning. I miss traveling. I miss the humid mangrove tang that hits you when you walk out of the airport in southwestern Florida and the angle of the sun when you’re driving around Los Angeles and the weird squawking birds in the trees of Sydney. I miss the whoosh of air that comes out of the Central Line tunnel at Marble Arch station in London, Berlin graffiti, the birds you can see walking the Beluga Slough trail near Homer, Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: ‘There Is No Safe Area’: In Kabul, Fear Has Taken Over
description: A new wave of violence and a growing uncertainty about the country’s future have left Afghans in the capital with a constant sense of fear.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — In Kabul’s uncertain present, fear and dread intertwine in a vise. Fear has become a way of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Raphael Warnock and the Legacy of Racial Tyranny
description: His victory in the Georgia Senate runoff made history, and also echoed it.
content: Lost in the horror and mayhem of the Jan. 6 Capitol riot was another momentous event that happened barely 12 hours earlier and hundreds of miles away: the election to the Senate of the Rev. Raphael Warnock of Georgia, the first Black Democratic senator from the South in the nation’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Phil Spector, the imprisoned music legend, spent his last days suffering with Covid.
description: Covid-19 has taken the life of Phil Spector, one of the most influential and successful record producers in rock ’n’ roll, who spent the last chapter of his life in prison for murder.
content: Covid-19 has taken the life of Phil Spector, one of the most influential and successful record producers in rock ’n’ roll, who spent the last chapter of his life in prison for murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Family Reaches $3.5 Million Settlement in Death of Maryland Football Player
description: Jordan McNair, a University of Maryland offensive lineman, collapsed from heatstroke during a practice in 2018 and died two weeks later.
content: The University of Maryland has reached a $3.5 million settlement agreement with the family of a football player who collapsed from heatstroke during a practice in May 2018 and died two weeks later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: How the Green Bay Packers routed the Los Angeles Rams to reach the N.F.C. title game.
description: Green Bay amassed 484 total yards of offense against the N.F.L.’s toughest defense.
content: [Follow our live Brown vs. Chiefs and Buccaneers vs. Saints coverage.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Sylvain Sylvain of the Proto-Punk Band New York Dolls Dies at 69
description: He was a core member of a group that had limited commercial success in the early 1970s and didn’t last long but proved hugely influential.
content: Sylvain Sylvain, a key member of the New York Dolls, the influential though short-lived proto-punk band whose outrageous shows at Max’s Kansas City and other venues paved the way for the era of the Ramones and the Sex Pistols, died on Wednesday at his home in Nashville. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: 7 Dead in Military Helicopter Crash in Southern Philippines
description: The helicopter had been on a supply run to troops in a remote, mountainous region where a hunt for communist rebels was taking place, the military said.
content: MANILA — Seven Philippine soldiers, including an air force colonel, died when the helicopter they were flying in crashed in the southern Philippines during a hunt for communist rebels over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flora Lee Peir
title: Precious Metal for Times Journalists: The Page One Plate
description: Carrying out this four-decade tradition at The Times has become more complicated because of the coronavirus pandemic. But it’s no less special.
content: The requests trickle in every two or three weeks: A reporter or photographer has made the front page of The New York Times for the first time. Could we honor them with a press plate of that day’s Page One?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: Dutch Police Clash With Protesters Denouncing Lockdown Measures
description: Police officers in riot gear used water cannons to disperse demonstrators in the center of Amsterdam opposed to government measures to contain the coronavirus.
content: Thousands of people, some throwing fireworks and stones, joined an unauthorized protest against the Dutch government’s coronavirus restrictions in Amsterdam on Sunday, and riot police officers used water cannons, batons, attack dogs and horses to disperse the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Nicole Hong
title: ‘I Answered the Call of My President’: Rioters Say Trump Urged Them On
description: The defense from Trump supporters arrested in the Capitol assault is emerging in court papers and interviews — and could play a role in impeachment proceedings.
content: In the two weeks since a raging mob stormed the Capitol, President Trump has shown no sign that he believes he shares responsibility for the worst incursion on the halls of Congress in more than two centuries. Shielding him further, his loyalists have started shifting blame for the attack to an array of distracting bogeymen: far-left anti-fascists, Black Lives Matter activists, even vague conspiracies of a setup involving Vice President Mike Pence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Kamala Harris will resign from her Senate seat on Monday.
description: Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, who remains a United States senator from California, plans to resign from her seat on Monday ahead of her inauguration two days later, a Harris aide said.
content: Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, who remains a United States senator from California, plans to resign from her seat on Monday ahead of her inauguration two days later, a Harris aide said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Eric Schmitt and Katie Benner
title: As Biden seeks to jump-start his term, law enforcement braces for possible violence.
description: With the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden just three days away, an air of anxiety hovered over Washington and state capitals across the country, as they braced for the possibility of more violence after right-wing extremists stormed the Capitol this month in a bid to stop President Trump’s loss from being certified.
content: With the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden just three days away, an air of anxiety hovered over Washington and state capitals across the country, as they braced for the possibility of more violence after right-wing extremists stormed the Capitol this month in a bid to stop President Trump’s loss from being certified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Prospect of Pardons in Final Days Fuels Market to Buy Access to Trump
description: The president’s allies have collected tens of thousands of dollars — and potentially much more — from people seeking pardons.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Trump prepares to leave office in days, a lucrative market for pardons is coming to a head, with some of his allies collecting fees from wealthy felons or their associates to push the White House for clemency, according to documents and interviews with more than three dozen lobbyists and lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Godwyn Morris and Paula Frisch
title: Unplug and Craft a Maze From Newspaper
description: With some thoughtful folding and a little tape, you can make your own hand-held game.
content: Mazes are ubiquitous in the video game world. Whether you are playing or designing a game, navigating turns and obstacles are the main actions of many computer games. Here is a chance to unplug and create your own hand-held challenge, figuring out the path, the hurdles and the way to win. For an additional method of play, and to mimic the process taught in beginner computer science classes, have one person operate the maze while someone else gives directions. Just fold, cut, roll, tape and crumple newspaper and you are ready to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Loews Hotels says it won’t host a fund-raiser with Senator Josh Hawley.
description: The decision to call off the event was the latest indication that many companies are distancing themselves from Republicans who voted to overturn the election results.
content: Loews Hotels said on Saturday that it would not host a fund-raiser with Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri, the latest indication that many companies are distancing themselves from Republicans who voted to overturn the election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: For Diversity Leaders in the Arts, Getting Hired Is Just the First Step
description: Cultural institutions are recruiting people of color to direct their transformation efforts. But bringing in one manager doesn’t mean the work is done.
content: Growing up in a working class family in Lawrence, Mass., Rosa Rodriguez-Williams said “museums were not part of my experience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Biden prepares to reverse Trump’s policies.
content: When he begins his presidency this week, Joe Biden will inherit a collection of crises unlike any in generations — the coronavirus pandemic, economic turmoil, racial strife and the aftermath of the assault on the Capitol. He plans to start his administration with dozens of executive directives in a 10-day blitz meant to signal a turning point for the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: How to Safely Join the Inauguration Festivities
description: There may not be huge crowds or evening balls, but you can still celebrate the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris.
content: The inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris on Jan. 20 will be different from past ceremonies. The Presidential Inaugural Committee is urging people to stay home to keep large crowds from potentially spreading the coronavirus, and there’s heightened security after a violent attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Drink Like a Cat
description: Jeff Stillman gets around.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Though this puzzle by Jeff Stillman was a heart-rending reminder of things lost to us — temporarily, hopefully — during the coronavirus pandemic, it was still a clever opening to our solving week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Security Tightens Around U.S. Capitol
description: The police and members of the National Guard filled the Capitol and the streets of Washington ahead of possible armed protests on Sunday and the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Jan. 20.
content: The police and members of the National Guard filled the Capitol and the streets of Washington ahead of possible armed protests on Sunday and the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Jan. 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Emily Rhyne and Ben Laffin
title: Capitol Under Lockdown Ahead of Inauguration
description: People able to enter the militarized perimeter around the U.S. Capitol caught a glimpse of an occupied city amid preparations for the presidential inauguration of Joe Biden.
content: People able to enter the militarized perimeter around the U.S. Capitol caught a glimpse of an occupied city amid preparations for the presidential inauguration of Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: True-Crime Podcast Puts Spotlight on Irish Coach Accused of Abuse
description: The Irish police are investigating accusations that George Gibney, a former swim coach for Ireland now living in the United States, sexually abused two swimmers who came forward after hearing the podcast about him.
content: DUBLIN — Years of harrowing media reports in Ireland about alleged child abuse by a prominent swimming coach failed to prompt action from the Irish authorities, but now a true-crime podcast may help bring him home from exile in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Celebrate Inauguration Day
description: Readers urge Americans not to let fear dominate a momentous day, and offer suggestions for former presidents and the media.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lincoln at the Bar? No
description: A historian writes that the notion that Lincoln enjoyed a beer is absurd. Also: Seniors in the pandemic; a union at Google; plight of single mothers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
